Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Does a large detritus pool enhance ecosystem resilience in response to an episodic perturbation?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Storm water runoff can erode and transport high levels of sediment and nutrients to lakes. This export is especially pronounced in the Midwestern U.S., where large areas of agriculture have left exposed soils that easily wash away during storms. These large pulses of sediments and nutrients to lakes during storms can affect drinking water quality, recreational opportunities, and commercial and sport fishing. It is expected that storms in the Midwestern U.S. will increase in severity and frequency over the next 100 years. This Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant will provide funds to understand how lakes will respond to storms under these changing conditions. In addition, this project will directly support the research of one doctoral student, and will provide hands-on research opportunities for undergraduate students.

This research will experimentally examine what factors contribute to lake ecosystem resilience following storm events, using replicated aquatic mesocosms (5000 liter tanks) that simulate conditions during large storm events in a lake. This research will answer three general questions: (1) Do larger detritus pools speed lake resilience (the time necessary for ecosystems to recover) following large storm events? (2) How do additions of sediment and nutrients that occur during large storm events affect lake recovery time? and (3) How do additions of sediment and nutrients and detritus pool size interactively affect lake resilience? The experiment will include manipulations of detritus pool size, hydraulic flushing (a physical disturbance that reduces the amount of algae), and addition of sediment and nutrients. A factorial design will be used to isolate the mechanisms that influence lake recovery following large storm events. Understanding how these factors interact is essential to understanding ecosystem resilience and for effective management of water quality in lakes and reservoirs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We expect the variability, frequency and severity of drought and precipitation events to increase in the coming century. This will strongly impact aquatic ecosystems, which can receive large subsidies from the terrestrial landscape, making them sensitive to variations in the hydrological cycle. However, the potential impacts of changing storm frequency and severity remain poorly understood. To address this knowledge gap, we used aquatic mesocosms in which we simulated conditions reflective of large storm event in a lake. We asked three specific questions. 

Question 1: Do larger detritus pool sizes enhance ecosystem resilience during storm events)?We measured ecosystem resilience as the inverse of the return time to pre-storm dynamics. We used multiple metrics to assess the perturbation response. We measured chlorophyll aconcentrations (proxy for algal biomass) and phytoplankton community composition, to assess how the autotrophic compartment was impacted and recovered from an simulated storm event. Additionally, I quantified resilience of ecosystem metabolism (gross primary production, ecosystem respiration, and net ecosystem production). 

Question 2: How do pulses of resources (sediment and nutrients) that occur during storm events modulate ecosystem resilience against flushing events? I measured how resource pulses during episodic perturbations influence resilience of autotrophs (chl aconcentrations; community composition) and ecosystem metabolism. Large resource pulses of sediment and nutrients are common in lakes following storm events. Substantial work has been dedicated to understanding the influence of these resource pulses (especially of limiting nutrients) on aquatic ecosystems, but surprisingly little is known about their effect on ecosystem resilience.  

Question 3: How do resource pulses (sediment and nutrients) and detritus pool size interactively affect ecosystem resilience against flushing?  I measured the interactive effect of resource pulses and detritus pools on the resilience of chl aconcentrations, phytoplankton community composition, and ecosystem metabolism. A large storm event can deliver large pulses of sediments and nutrients in addition to flushing biomass from a lake. As these effects seldom occur in isolation, it is important to understand the interactive relationship that resources pulses and biomass flushing have on ecosystem resilience.  

We successfully simulated a large storm event, that mimicked conditions observed in lakes. We found that ecosystem metabolism returned to pre-storm baseline conditions within 4 days. Interestingly, the presence and size of the sediment detrital pool did not affect the resiliency of ecosystem metabolism. We found the green algae were the dominant algal group present. However, treatments with sediment detrital pools had consistently lower concentrations of green algae. Because of this, total chlorophyll was lowest in treatments with sediment detrital pools.  However, sediment detrital pools did not seem to inhibit cyanobacteria. Green algae experienced a bloom after the first simulated storm event with a nutrient pulse, but only in treatments that did not contain detrital pools. Cyanobacteria experienced a bloom after the first simulated storm event with a nutrient pulse, but only in treatments that contained detrital pools. 

            These findings suggest that increased storm events will promote algal blooms, likely by adding nutrients (nitrogen, phosphorus) that limit algal growth. How phytoplankton communities respond to increasing storm severity and frequency will depend on the extent to which the water column interacts with benthic detrital pools. In shallow well-mixed lakes, storm events may favor cyanobacteria blooms. In these lakes, the water column remains highly connected to the benthic zone. In deeper stratified lakes, storm events may favor green algae. In stratified lakes, thermal stratification reduces connectivity between the surface waters and the benthic zone. Understanding what factors contribute to ecosystem resilience in the face of increasing storm  events is essential to understanding how climate change will directly impact water quality and the ecosystem services provided by lake ecosystems.
